record.pwc_title: Say ‘bye, bye, bye’ to Lotus Notes
record.pwc_body: Say ‘bye, bye, bye’ to Lotus Notes Say ‘bye, bye, bye’ to Lotus Notes Chief Data Office Feb. 4, 2019 We’re sunsetting Lotus Notes in phases -- last month we deleted all of our old email archives, releasing more than 100 terabytes of redundant, obsolete and trivial data. The next step on this simplification journey is retiring unneeded Lotus Notes applications and databases. We’ll start that process Feb. 28. Read on to find out how to prepare. What to expect First, rest assured that any business-critical tasks currently operating in Lotus Notes applications and databases (things like Advisory map, financial reporting applications and work request databases) will not be retired until they have been successfully replatformed — and we’ll give you plenty of notice before that happens. However, in addition to those “high-usage” applications and databases, we’ve also identified thousands of low-user-count applications and databases that may have little business value. On Feb. 28, we will begin turning off access for those low-user-count Lotus Notes applications and databases. After a sufficient period of inactivity, retired applications and databases will be archived and eventually deleted (except those subject to an OGC Legal Hold). But wait! What about the [fill-in-the-blank] application? I need that! Your IT and business leaders have confidence we’ve identified and made plans to replatform the Lotus Notes applications and databases that have business value. However, you can double-check to see whether an application or database you use regularly is scheduled to be turned off: Navigate to this database review tool. If you discover an application or database that needs to be kept beyond Feb. 28, 2019 — including anything subject to an OGC Legal Hold — simply follow the system prompts to request an exception. Your IT leaders will review your request to help you retain the information you need or to replatform to a new system. After Feb. 28, if you realize an application or database that’s been turned off needs to be recovered, you can have it temporarily reactivated by submitting a ticket through PwC’s Service Hub. We’ll provide access for a period of time and help you find a more tech-enabled way to manage related tasks going forward. Still have questions? Visit our Data Remediation page for FAQs, tools and resources to help you find, move and appropriately store any information in Lotus Notes that continues to hold business value. Get help! Visit PwC’s Service Hub for a full list of support options, including one-on-one reservations for IT support. Next steps toward moving away from old systems Replatforming and retiring Lotus Notes applications and databases is an important step — but we also have some other outdated systems that need retiring. Here’s what you can expect as we keep moving forward: This spring, we’ll prepare to turn off (and eventually delete) legacy shared drives. By the end of FY19, we’ll put in place a new 18-month retention period on our current Lotus Notes mailboxes. (In plain English, this means we’ll start automatically deleting Lotus Notes emails when they hit the 18-month-old milestone.) We’ll also introduce similar retention policies for our Google Mail and calendar events -- and lengthier data retention policies for Google Drive, Google Keep, Sites and G+ content. (We’ll give you plenty of notice, but you can start to prepare now by refreshing yourself on our systems for storing and managing records and for collaboration.) Later this year, we’ll be ready to delete everyone’s last Lotus Notes email archive and stop issuing Lotus Notes profiles to new joiners. Remind me: Why are we doing this? The way we approach data as a firm is changing. As part of a multi-year data journey, we’ve implemented robust, modern systems for storing and managing records and for collaboration. At the same time, we’re retiring outdated data storage systems; deleting redundant, obsolete and trivial data; and implementing best-in-class guidance for actively managing the data lifecycle. Top News

record.pwc_title: We are IFS: Laurel Ostiguy follows her dreams of becoming an author
record.pwc_body: We are IFS: Laurel Ostiguy follows her dreams of becoming an author We are IFS: Laurel Ostiguy follows her dreams of becoming an author IFS Aug. 6, 2018 “We are IFS” focuses on fun and inspiring stories from our IFS colleagues. Laurel Ostiguy, a Boston-based manager in National Office Services, couldn't ignore her dream of becoming an author any longer. "For a long time I tried to quell the overwhelming urge to write a book, until it basically wrote itself," she said. Laurel always knew she had a story inside her, even as a child. When she found herself with a two-hour, round-trip commute a few years ago, the time was right. "I had plenty of time to think the story through and literally record my thoughts, using my iPhone," she said. "And one day, I just began writing it!" She had help along the way, including advice to self-publish. "A friend introduced me to an author who provided tips on how to network and find an editor, cover designer and photographer," she shared. The more people she spoke with, the more it all seemed to fall into place. "At one point I said to myself, 'I really am doing this,' and just kept going." Her first novel, Last Goodbye, was published in 2015 and took four years to write. It was met with positive acclaim, but not before she hired beta readers to review it. "Beta readers are trained to actually rip a transcript apart to give you the absolute painful truth about your story and your writing," she said. "In my case, the feedback they provided was constructive -- and invaluable. When you get a compliment from them, it's a very big deal." Longing to Be followed in 2016, Lying in Wait comes out later this year and Lessons in Love will be released in 2020. All of her books share an ongoing storyline. "The premise of the series follows the journey of several characters from their freshman year of college through graduation, with lots of twists and turns," she said. How does she find the time to write? "I take advantage of PwC’s flexible work environment and now work from home,” she said. “Without that lengthy commute, I have more flexibility to write in the evenings and on weekends. My husband and two young children are very supportive. I love my job at PwC and I love that I can pursue my dream as an author!" A role model for aspiring authors Book signing gigs are another perk. "I love to encourage young aspiring writers,” she said. “Making connections is what it’s all about.” Laurel also donates her books to libraries and auctions. "Self-publishing is very popular these days, and I really recommend it," she said. This means she covers the cost of proofing, printing and design. The books are printed but also available online for Kindle, Nook, iPhone, Amazon and more. "And it's always a treat to read positive reviews, whether they appear in a local newspaper, on Amazon or even on Instagram," she said. Laurel is thrilled to see her passion come to life. "I used to walk in bookstores and say 'why not me?'" Indeed, why not? Find out more about Laurel and her books at www.laurelostiguy.com. Who’s inspiring you in a unique way? Help us tell their #TeamPwC story! Reach out with your “We are IFS” story ideas. Top News

record.pwc_title: Integrated Solution FOR THE WIN at NOVA Chemicals
record.pwc_body: Integrated Solution FOR THE WIN at NOVA Chemicals Integrated Solution FOR THE WIN at NOVA Chemicals Advisory March 14, 2019 What were NOVA’s key objectives? NOVA’s Gen Z program was focused on an enterprise-wide, multi-year digital transformation. The key objective was to implement SAP cloud solutions, in particular SAP Integrated Business Planning (IBP), to restructure the antiquated supply chain and financial planning business processes, modernize the aging IT platform to decrease operational costs and streamline the supply chain to create a completely integrated ecosystem that's transparent to all functions involved. What was our proposed solution for NOVA? Using the Integrated Business Planning (IBP) Integrated Solution, and a BXT delivery method, we proposed a unifying supply chain platform leveraging the “Power or the Firm” with best practices from the IBP Integrated Solution playbook, and input from our strategy, management and technology consulting areas across the US and Canada. To solidify the relationship with NOVA and secure the win, we demonstrated chemical industry thought leadership combined with clear articulation of how PwC’s SAP IBP, IDeA, and SCOOP digital tools would deliver value. During orals, we made NOVA feel comfortable by taking extra time during breaks to walk through PwC’s pre-built digital enablers, helping NOVA understand the experience of working with us. What is Integrated Business Planning Integrated Solution? Integrated business planning (IBP) is a strategy for connecting the planning functions (sales and operations planning) in an organization to align operations and strategy with the organization's financial performance (financial planning and analysis). IBP includes functions such as demand planning, sales revenue planning, inventory optimization, product cost planning, detailed scheduling and operational expense planning. The IBP Integrated Solution team has built a delivery playbook with guidance, tools and templates to leverage, and project plans to help deliver in a repeatable and efficient way. What value will NOVA see using our solution? The Integrated Business Planning Integrated Solution will not only drive a one-time working capital reduction of $23 million for NOVA but also reduce over $1 million in annually recurring expenses. Equally important, this solution will retire the aging supply chain IT tools and create improved cross-functional visibility of key supply chain information. To date, we have already identified $12 million in finished goods inventory reduction opportunities and leveraged PwC’s SCOOP Intelligent Forecasting Platform (IFP) to improve forecast accuracy by greater than 15 percent. Meet the team! Want to learn more about Integrated Solutions? Check out Consulting Source and the Integrated Solutions Learning Hub. Top News

record.pwc_title: Do you work with our individual clients? Remember these FROR rules and other contracting protocols
record.pwc_description: Follow the prescribed protocols for contract language and policies - Financial Reporting Oversight Roles (FROR), Consent to Disclosure of Tax Return Information and Privacy Policy Notices.
record.pwc_body: Do you work with our individual clients? Remember these FROR rules and Do you work with our individual clients? Remember these FROR rules and other contracting protocols One Firm Risk Organization Jan. 23, 2019 As part of our continuous efforts to support the Tax line of service through regular communications, we are calling attention to the following contract language and policies -- Financial Reporting Oversight Roles (FROR), Consent to Disclosure of Tax Return Information and Privacy Policy Notices. Given the regulatory environment in which we work and the independence issues that could result from a failure to comply with the Tax LOS policy in these areas, it is important that engagement teams working with our individual clients understand and follow the prescribed protocols. The Tax Engagement Compliance Review Program and Office Review Program results have highlighted the need for increased diligence from our teams to include all required language in engagement contracts, obtain the required confirmations from our clients and execute the delivery of services in accordance with our risk management and independence guidance. When contracting with individual clients (including spouses and financially dependent relatives), engagement teams should remember the following: Engagement teams are responsible for ensuring that they do not provide tax services to individuals who are within the scope of PCAOB Rule 3523. Providing services to an individual (including spouses and financially dependent relatives) in a FROR position is an impermissible service and could result in a reportable independence violation. The Engagement Letters Index contains links to the templates for individual tax compliance services which includes FROR and Consent to Disclosure of Tax Return Information language requesting confirmation and consent from the individual client before engaging to provide services. The engagement letter templates used for individual services provides a Privacy Notice that is included with the annual engagement letter as an attachment. Our Privacy Policy provides a better understanding to our clients of our commitment to keeping client personal information confidential. RECOMMENDATION – If you are providing individual tax services and you are not in the PFS practice, be sure to make use of the PCS Q&RM Busy Season Toolkit and engagement letter templates or preferably, enlist a PFS specialist to assist you through the engagement set-up process. Financial Reporting Oversight Roles (FROR) FROR rules are covered under PCAOB Rule 3523. In summary, a registered public accounting firm is not independent of its audit client if the firm, or any affiliate of the firm, during the audit engagement period provides any tax service to a person in a financial reporting oversight role at the audit client. The Tax LOS has issued policies and tools in this area to assist engagement teams in obtaining the necessary sign-offs and acknowledgements from their individual clients. Our Review Program results highlight that engagement teams are not consistently obtaining client verification as to whether or not the client(s) is/are in a financial reporting oversight role (FROR) in the following key areas: Engagements for an individual who receives services under the terms of a Corporate Compliance or Consulting contract. Such engagements require FROR confirmations from all individuals for which tax returns are prepared. Engagements for an individual who receives services under the terms of a Family Office Services or Corporate Executive Program contract. Such engagements require FROR confirmations from all individuals for which tax returns are prepared. Engagements performed under a multi-year contract. Such engagements require FROR confirmation annually. Engagements to perform FBAR services for an individual who is an authorized signatory. Such engagements require FROR confirmation (see Foreign Bank Account Reporting (FBAR)). Consent to Disclosure of Tax Return Information Section 7216 consent must be obtained for all tax compliance and consulting engagements for individuals due to the nature of our business operations (e.g., use of GDM resources, third party contractors, back office support, etc.) and if the client requests that we disclose the client's tax return information to their representatives or professional advisors (e.g., the client's legal counsel, secretary, head (or CFO) of family office, etc.). This consent must be obtained prior to disclosing information to third parties. The consent must be signed by the client. Please note that the Consent to Disclosure of Tax Return Information must be obtained annually, including in the case of a multi-year contract. Do not reduce the font size of the Consent to Disclosure of Tax Return Information document below 12 points. This font size is required in order to comply with regulations and procedures under Section 7216. Privacy Policy Notice Tax LOS policy requires that privacy notices be sent to clients when providing individual tax (compliance and consulting) services. The GLBA Privacy Notice must be provided when the client relationship commences. For existing clients, an annual notice must be provided every calendar year. Engagement teams should be sure to use the most current engagement letter templates from the Engagement Letters Index. record.pwc_title: What do credit cards, your immediate family and you all have in common? Personal independence
record.pwc_body: What do credit cards, your immediate family and you all have in common What do credit cards, your immediate family and you all have in common? Personal independence Ethics & Compliance Jan. 2, 2019 If you are required to maintain independence, your immediate family’s (spouse/spouse equivalent and dependents’) relationships can impact your personal independence. Here are some examples: Aggregate credit card balances Do you know which financial institutions issue the credit cards you and your immediate family use? Check the back of each credit card to determine the issuer. If you’re a covered person to the issuer: Pay your bill on time without incurring late fees. Keep the aggregate carrying balance (of all cards held by you and your immediate family) with any issuer below $10,000. Watch this short clip about paying attention to those credit cards. Online payment accounts Remember Jasmine from this year’s Annual Independence, Ethics & Compliance training? Ranga, Jasmine’s spouse equivalent, had a PayPal account she used for her fantasy football league and Jasmine was a covered person to PayPal. Certain websites and apps (such as PayPal, and Twinspires) act like digital wallets and hold money “on account.” If you are a covered person, you cannot maintain a balance in these accounts as they are considered “uninsured deposits.” It’s easy to start the discussion with your immediate family. Download and share this quick guide on “Personal Independence at Home.” Also, before providing any services, make sure you (and, by extension, your immediate family) are independent of the client. Remember: You cannot provide any audit services or 10 or more hours of non-audit services to a restricted entity if you have an investment in that entity or an affiliate. When providing services to an unrestricted entity, you cannot begin investing in that entity until six months after you have stopped providing services. You may keep investments previously held before working on the engagement, but you cannot sell or buy shares until the six month cooling off period passes. If you’re not sure of the restriction status or if you’re allowed to provide services, contact the Compliance Resource Center before providing any services. Learn more on the US Ethics and Compliance Personal Independence site or by calling the Compliance Resource Center at 1-877-PwC-Help (877-792-4357), option 5 in the US or 813-351-6491 outside the US. You may also submit a ticket or use the chat feature found on the Compliance Resource Center (CRC) Spark page. Top News

record.pwc_title: PwC Dallas delivers hope with teamwork and digital skills
record.pwc_body: PwC Dallas delivers hope with teamwork and digital skills PwC Dallas delivers hope with teamwork and digital skills People Team Jan. 21, 2019 Our Dallas colleagues made an extraordinary commitment that brought our values to life and carried on Bo Jean’s tradition of kindness. With One Firm spirit and enhanced digital skills, the team delivered holiday cheer to more than 100 children in the community. For many years, PwC Dallas has proudly partnered with the Dallas Children’s Advocacy Center (DCAC), a local nonprofit whose mission is to improve the lives of abused children and provide leadership on child abuse issues. Last September, the Dallas office generously agreed to provide holiday gifts to 130 children as part of DCAC’s Holiday of Hope campaign, donating coats, pajamas, and other items on their wishlists. The campaign helped 2,200 of Dallas County’s most severely abused children during the holiday season. When the team received the children’s wish lists from DCAC in December, they realized the enormity of the project. Hundreds of gifts needed to be donated, organized and delivered -- in two weeks. The team needed a holiday miracle. One Firm spirit makes it happen “We had a lot of work to do with very little time,” said Associate Preston Davison. “We needed to purchase over 400 gifts. The gifts then needed to be sorted by family and child, and delivered to DCAC.” The office came together in true One Firm spirit to make the seemingly impossible task a success. Preston leveraged newly acquired digital skills to facilitate the process. “We started by creating an Amazon Wishlist, and then we leveraged UiPath and Alteryx workflows to track our purchases.” Thanks to the generosity and kindness of our PwC family, all of the items were purchased in just a matter of days. The Deals team alone sponsored 60 of the 130 children. And because kindness is contagious, a local Tax team was inspired to raise an additional $3,000 to sponsor 30 more children in need. “It was an honor to represent PwC when we delivered the gifts,” Preston said. “To see the tears and the smiling faces as we kept bringing in bag after bag of gifts was an incredible experience. I’m glad to have played a part in it.” The Dallas team plans to take part in the Holiday of Hope campaign again in 2019 -- just another example of how they continue spreading kindness to others. Note: Check out the latest episode of our Well, well, well podcast to hear more from our Dallas team on their Holiday of Hope experience. Also, keep sharing the kindness and add to our collective reach here. Top News

record.pwc_title: Tech tip: Set it and forget it
record.pwc_description: Google Mail’s new Schedule Send feature gives you the option to choose when your email is sent to recipients.
record.pwc_body: Tech tip: Set it and forget it Tech tip: Set it and forget it PwC Technology May 13, 2019 Working late and don’t want to disturb your client with an after-hours email? Schedule it to send first thing in the morning. Are you a super-planner and want to set up a series of reminder emails to your team? Schedule them in advance. Don’t want to forget birthday greetings? Schedule them while you’re thinking about it. Google Mail’s new Schedule Send feature gives you the option to choose when your email is sent to recipients. Now, you can enjoy even more flexibility: Work on your own schedule, but deliver messages when it works best for your clients and colleagues. Scheduling an email is a cinch. Simply compose your email — but instead of hitting send, select the dropdown menu on the blue Send button. (If you have “Send and Archive” enabled, select the white send button.) Select “Schedule send” and choose the time and date from the pop-up menu. The time you select is local to your PC, so account for any difference in time zones. Taking it mobile To use the Schedule Send function on mobile, it only works in the Gmail app (which you can download from PwC’s App Store). To schedule an email on your mobile device, select the three dots next to the send icon and select “Schedule send.” Where do all the emails go? You’ll find scheduled emails in a folder called “Scheduled” (just under the “Sent” folder). From there, you can cancel or make adjustments to sending details. When working offline, it’s possible to schedule emails to be sent at a later time. However, emails will not be sent until you re-establish connection to the network. This means that if you are working offline on the plane, be sure to schedule emails to be sent after you reconnect to the network. Top News

record.pwc_title: Tech tip: 6 ways to be an inbox hero
record.pwc_body: Tech tip: 6 ways to be an inbox hero Tech tip: 6 ways to be an inbox hero Chief Data Office Jan. 18, 2019 The way we approach data as a firm is changing. It’s time to rethink how you manage the data you work with daily. A great place to start is with healthy email management. These tips will help you take control of your email and make it work better for you. Avoid the temptation to use your inbox as your to-do list. Turn off email notifications, which distract from strategic tasks. Instead, designate certain times during the day to focus on email. Be strategic when reviewing your email. Try a quick triage system to delete, archive, take immediate action or “star” a message to handle later. By making decisions the first time you view a message, you’ll move through your email more efficiently. (Refresh on the records management and retention policy.) Set up labels for messages you need for a finite period (for instance, for a specific project). You’ll have quick access while you need it, without clogging up your inbox. And it will be easy to delete or transfer the entire group of emails to the appropriate system of record when the project is complete. (Watch the recent Connect & Learn on mailbox labels.) Become an “inbox zero” hero. Clear out your inbox — and keep it clean. If you’ve got hundreds of emails piled up, try assigning them (temporarily) an “old email” label. You’ll still have easy access while you’re adjusting to your new inbox zero habit. Speaking of storage systems … don’t use email as a filing cabinet. Important info and attachments should be saved to shared environments like Google Drive (for collaboration) or systems of record (for project and client records). Make use of other communication channels like Google Chat and Salesforce Chatter when appropriate and in compliance with business rules. Don’t be guilty of sending one-word emails (“Thanks!”), and do think twice before choosing “reply all.” More to know For more strategies to take control of your email, search “email” on Fathom Search. Visit Data remediation @ PwC for more on the steps we’re taking to sunset outdated data-storage systems (like Lotus Notes and shared drives), delete “redundant, obsolete and trivial” data (or “ROT,” like old emails), and put in place new guidance for actively managing the data lifecycle. #PwCUSIT Top News

record.pwc_title: Wait…are these Tax services permissible? Follow 5 steps to analyze permissibility of services
record.pwc_description: Start with the chart of Tax services and related SOPS for your evaluation of the Independence threats and related safeguards.
record.pwc_body: Wait…are these Tax services permissible? Follow 5 steps to analyze per Wait…are these Tax services permissible? Follow 5 steps to analyze permissibility of services One Firm Risk Organization May 23, 2019 Before proposing on or providing services to a restricted client, engagement teams must consider the permissibility of those services, taking into consideration the current restriction status of the client in CES (i.e., SEC, AICPA and/or GIP). In order to help engagement teams assess the permissibility of services, the Statements of Permitted Services ("SOPS") and US Independence Policy ("USIP") were drafted. The SOPS and USIP should be used to determine how to apply PwC’s Independence policies regarding non-audit services to be provided to restricted clients and related entities. In general, an Independence analysis utilizing the SOPS and USIP involves an evaluation of the Independence threats that may arise with respect to a particular service offering and related safeguards that, if implemented, may eliminate or reduce such threats to an acceptable level. All SOPS follow a standard format: Section 1: What this SOPS Covers – describes the services or issues covered in the specific SOPS; Section 2: Application of Global Independence Policy (“GIP”) – provides guidance on what is/is not permitted and/or what is permitted with safeguards for GIP restricted clients; Section 3: Nature of the Independence Threat – provides an analysis of the main threats to PwC’s audit Independence that may arise from the services or issues covered by the SOPS; Section 4: Safeguards – provides guidance as to safeguards that may be applied generally or in specific circumstances to mitigate identified risks to Independence; and Section 5: Supplemental Guidance for SEC-Restricted Entities – provides guidance for SEC restricted clients that is additional to, or different from, the GIP requirements discussed in Section 2 and which must be followed when providing services to SEC restricted clients. Section 7200 and Section 7400 of USIP provide guidance for SEC and AICPA restricted clients that is additional to, and occasionally different from, the guidance contained in the SOPS. Section 7200 and Section 7400 of USIP should be reviewed in connection with the SOPS and followed when providing services to SEC and/or AICPA restricted clients. The following steps provide high-level guidelines on how to use the SOPS and USIP to perform an Independence analysis: Action 1: Confirm that you have identified the appropriate SOPS for the proposed services (a user-friendly SOPS chart has been created and can be used as a starting point in any Independence analysis). Action 2: If providing services to a SEC restricted client, start with Section 5 of the SOPS and Section 7200 of USIP to establish whether the proposed services are permissible per SEC guidelines. If not permissible, you will need to reconsider/restructure the service offering as SEC Independence rules do not permit the implementation of safeguards to eliminate or reduce threats to an acceptable level when providing services to a SEC restricted client. Action 3: If the services are permissible with respect to a SEC restricted client or if the client is AICPA and/or GIP restricted (only), you must verify that the services are permissible per Section 7400 of USIP (for AICPA restricted clients) and/or Section 2 of the SOPS (for GIP restricted clients). Action 4: If the services are permissible, determine the nature of the Independence threats as described in Section 3 of the SOPS and the corresponding safeguards to be applied as described in Section 4 of the SOPS. Action 5: Once the Independence analysis has been documented, engagement teams must include the analysis along with the "Threats and Safeguards Analysis Form" in the "Relevant Policy and Threats and Safeguards" section of the AFS (Authorisation For Services form) for approval by the CES Responsible Partner (and the U.S. AFS Review team, where required). For additional information regarding permissibility, please visit the Independence microsite or contact any member of the OFRO Tax team with questions. Top News

record.pwc_title: Tax and wealth planning questions? We’ve got a guide for that!
record.pwc_body: Tax and wealth planning questions? We’ve got a guide for that! Tax and wealth planning questions? We’ve got a guide for that! record.pwc_title: What a save! 5 ways your HSA puts money in your pocket
record.pwc_body: What a save! 5 ways your HSA puts money in your pocket What a save! 5 ways your HSA puts money in your pocket National Benefits Nov. 12, 2018 This article applies to PwC UnitedHealthcare medical plan participants. Are you contributing to your Health Savings Account (HSA)? You can start, increase or decrease HSA contributions at any time at Benefits Express Online. And if you’re enrolled in the High or Middle Deductible Plan, PwC puts money in your HSA each pay day. Here are five reasons you should save as much as you can in your HSA. 1. You get triple tax savings. Contributions to your HSA are not taxed. Funds in your HSA grow tax-free. Withdrawals for qualified health care expenses are also tax-free. 2. You don’t lose what you don’t spend. There’s no "use it or lose it" rule for funds in your HSA. Any money you don’t use by the end of the year rolls over to the next year -- and even into retirement. So, you don't have to know what kind of health care expenses you'll incur in order to contribute to an HSA. 3. You HSA dollars earn interest and potentially investment returns. Your HSA cash balance earns interest based on the applicable rate for your balance. Plus, you’re eligible to invest any portion of your HSA balance in excess of $1,000 in available mutual fund options. These options comply with PwC's independence requirements and you don’t need to enter these investments through the Independence Checkpoint system. 4. You can use your HSA for anyone in your family. Use HSA dollars to pay for the qualified medical expenses for anyone you claim on your taxes, even if they’re not enrolled in your medical plan. 5. You can take it with you! Your HSA is portable. It goes with you -- even if you leave PwC. Learn more and earn Well-Being Rewards For more information about HSAs and the benefits of maximizing your contributions, view the online course Using Your Health Savings Account Effectively. When you do, you earn 500 points in the Well-Being Rewards Program.* (Earn up to 1,000 points per quarter for completing online financial well-being courses. Additional courses in the learning series currently include estate planning, debt consolidation, early career financial planning and retirement planning. We expect to introduce additional online courses in the coming months.) *Allow ~1 week for points to post in your Well-Being Rewards statement for PwC Envision activities. Here’s how to access the online course: On the desktop platform: Go to the Well-Being Rewards Program Select Programs from the top of the page Scroll down to Financial dimension in left navigation bar Click Managing my Finances Select the Health Savings Account Course On the app: Select the menu icon on the top-left side of the screen Select Dimensions to access financial tools and resources Click Financial and then Managing My Finances Select Financial Well Being Courses Choose the Health Savings Account Course Not registered for Well-Being Rewards yet? Go to http://join.virginpulse.com/PwCWellBeingRewards_US to activate your account. Then download the Virgin Pulse app from PwC’s App Store on your iPhone/iPad, or the Google Play for Work Store on your Android. Top News

record.pwc_title: Ensuring family business succession doesn’t turn into family feud
record.pwc_body: Ensuring family business succession doesn’t turn into family feud Ensuring family business succession doesn’t turn into family feud Private Company Services Sept. 13, 2018 Running a family-owned business comes with a personal investment of blood, sweat, and tears. For many, the question of what happens to that business after the owner retires is fraught with challenges. Charlie Carr and Belinda Sneddon, Managing Directors in PwC's US Family Enterprise Advisory Services group, share their insights from working with family business owners on continuity and succession planning challenges. After working hard to establish their businesses, how well are family business owners planning to preserve their wealth and legacy for future generations? Belinda: There is so much focus on establishing and growing the business that owners often are not thinking about continuity planning. It’s interesting because the characteristics that make them so good at building their business may be the same ones that make it so hard for them to bring others into the decision making and management processes. This is an area where family business owners could benefit from guidance around the need for appropriate planning, communication, and execution. Charlie: Unfortunately, we see many first generation family members who don't have answers for the next generation — and don't want to discuss it. This may be the worst possible response, as they need to be more strategic so they can identify shortcomings and develop ways to address them. What are some of the biggest issues related to continuity and succession planning? Charlie: First generation businesses are often run by a controlling owner. In the second and third generations, siblings or cousins may need to work together. Each family member has different skills, interests, and goals. While some may be competing to run the company, others might be uninvolved and more concerned about distribution levels. So families need to balance these different interests. Belinda: Communicating these plans is something that many families find challenging. Where communication is missing or weak, the resulting lack of transparency can cause rifts in the family and problems for the business. Even where communication is strong, it is important not to assume awareness equates to acceptance/buy-in. Charlie: At the end of the day, families need to have a governance model that evolves as they move across generations because the model that worked for the prior generation may not work for the next one. What steps do you recommend families take to set up for long-term success? Charlie: During the upcoming Continuity and Succession Planning webinar on September 19th, Belinda and I will talk about three key steps that family business should take related to strategy, communication, and execution. We'll discuss why each step is important and share examples of the pitfalls we’ve seen families encounter at each step. Attend, and invite your clients to attend, the Continuity and Succession Planning webinar sponsored by PwC and Family Business Magazine on Wednesday, September 19 from 2 pm - 3 pm ET. Top News

record.pwc_title: A yogi in Bali: One PwCer’s mindful sabbatical
record.pwc_description: Lanie Potgieter used her career milestone sabbatical to disconnect and immerse herself in yoga instructor training.
record.pwc_body: A yogi in Bali: One PwCer’s mindful sabbatical A yogi in Bali: One PwCer’s mindful sabbatical People Team June 7, 2019 Reaching the senior manager or director level is a significant career accomplishment worth celebrating. As part of our Rewards Strategy, eligible newly promoted client service senior managers and IFS directors are awarded a four-week sabbatical -- a chance to unwind, recharge and truly focus on their well-being through Be well, work well -- a key component of Your Tomorrow. In 2012, Lanie Potgieter left her home of Cape Town, South Africa for a short-term international tour in New York City. Little did she know, the move would become permanent — and was the start of an incredible journey of personal growth. “Being a senior associate in PwC’s New York City office (at the time) was both a thrill and challenge,” Lanie admits. “Although I was working long hours and feeling a little homesick, the experience provided a new perspective on well-being.” To keep up with the fast-pace of the Big Apple, Lanie recognized the importance of energy renewal. With the encouragement of her partner and mentor John Gottfried, she decided to invest more time in well-being and find balance by trying yoga. “Being on the yoga mat allows me to feel fully present and melts away my stress,” said Lanie. “I learned how to balance assertiveness and softness and quickly began to see how that balance was having a positive effect on my relationships and approach to work.” Yoga had such a profound effect on Lanie that she decided to become an instructor to help others discover the many health benefits of yoga and mindfulness. In November 2018, she used her career milestone sabbatical to attend an intensive yoga training program in Bali. “I researched many teacher training programs and ultimately decided to travel far from home,” she says. “I wanted to completely disconnect and immerse myself in the experience. The 24-day program was incredible!” Although yoga works for Lanie, she recognizes it may not be for everyone. She advises people to Be well, work well by finding what they enjoy doing to re-energize and sticking with it. “Not every yoga practice is easy for me. Some days are better than others. But I always return to my mat, because I know in the end, it’s going to make me feel great and help me be my best self.” Visit our Rewards Strategy site to learn more about milestone sabbaticals and PwC's Career Milestone program. Contact: US_People-Communications@pwc.com Top News

record.pwc_title: 90 reasons to smile: Matthew Bower wins and loses with Be well, work well
record.pwc_body: 90 reasons to smile: Matthew Bower wins and loses with Be well, work w 90 reasons to smile: Matthew Bower wins and loses with Be well, work well People Team March 2, 2018 Director Matthew Bower's well-being story began with a shock -- in the guise of a bathroom scale. "After joining PwC in 2014, and relocating from Connecticut to Chicago, I was living large, literally, enjoying everything city life had to offer, including dining out every night in fancy restaurants," he said. But the good times left their mark when Matthew stepped on that scale and reality set in. "I thought it must be defective,” he said. “I was 40 pounds over what I thought I weighed.” That startling moment propelled him to make a complete lifestyle change. He joined a gym, hired a personal trainer, and began eating healthier and tracking his food every day. It didn’t take long to start seeing results. "I was encouraged by my progress and stayed on course, including bringing healthy snacks and lunches to work, limiting restaurant meals and continuing these good habits even when traveling for work," Matthew said. His loss, his gain Inevitably, the scale went down, and down. "I lost a total of 90 pounds over the span of about three years," he said. He was even featured in his gym's "Transformation Tuesday" promotional campaign. Matthew also realized he was already living the principles of Be well, work well in many ways, and began following the suggestions outlined in the Habit Bank to stay energized. "I'm glad the firm is committed to well-being; it’s so important to our success and our people," he said. He focuses on mental and spiritual energy through yoga, reading and being more aware of his spirituality in general. Matthew's team is supportive of his dramatic journey, and they all enjoy sharing tips. "We have an Instagram account for The habit challenge. We call ourselves “Energizin’ is a Habit, Get Like Me,’” he said. They have committed to "stepping away from the screen" and "hydrating your mind." "My team pushes me to continue to be a champion of living a healthy lifestyle," he said. Matthew also takes advantage of the Well-Being Rewards program by logging his gym time, nutritionist visits, yearly physicals and more -- banking his rewards all year. "I use them to get my wife an extra Christmas present," he said. He's also a member of PwC Chicago’s Health and Wellness Committee, which promotes many of the practices of The habit challenge. For those struggling with weight issues, Matthew has a message: "It can be done -- I am proof. Despite the hours, client dinners, happy hours and travel, it’s still possible to live a healthy lifestyle and meet the demands of our clients. Good habits take time to take hold; don't get discouraged. And please contact me if I can help." Oh, and pizza and ice cream are not off limits. "I still indulge,” Matthew said. "But it's the exception now, not the rule." Do you have a Be well, work well story to share? Let us know! And don't forget the Your Tomorrow, Our Time Off challenge -- if we meet our goals, we’ll get the entire July 4 week off! For the Be well, work well component, 90% of us must do three things: Take the Energy Audit Visit the Habit Bank Be part of at least one Be well, work well team plan Matthew Bowers, before and after Top News

record.pwc_title: Engaging a third party supplier? Avoid buyer’s remorse
record.pwc_body: Engaging a third party supplier? Avoid buyer’s remorse Engaging a third party supplier? Avoid buyer’s remorse Ethics & Compliance March 27, 2019 Consider this scenario: You want to impress your client with a new presentation tool. You find the perfect tool online and it's only $20 a month! You grab your AMEX*, agree to the terms, and you're done. Would you have made this purchase if you knew this tool sends confidential client data that is in your presentation back to the software company? Or that the company’s owner is allegedly accused of patent infringement and trade-secret theft? Oh, and you missed the part that the version you purchased is only for personal use, not for business use. Sounds scary, right? It should. Certain suppliers present higher risk to the firm, and it is critical that we perform the proper due diligence before we contract with such suppliers. The Supplier Risk Management Program, part of the Procurement process, helps you proactively identify and mitigate risks -- like the ones identified in the scenario above. What you should do when engaging a supplier Make sure you submit your request to Procurement through Request It if your supplier request meets any one of the following conditions: The supplier may have access to, process or host client or firm information. The contract or purchase value may be greater than or equal to $50,000 ($10,000 for contract or purchases initiated in Mexico). The software may be used by, with or resold to clients (including being incorporated into client deliverables or market facing offerings). Be sure to reference the “When to Engage Procurement” section of the Procurement policy as soon as you think you might need a supplier as the policy may be updated throughout the year. *Purchasing software or IT services using a corporate AMEX credit card is prohibited by the firm. Be sure to submit requests for software not available in Software Installer or Software Center by submitting a request using the IT Request Form. Learn more If you have any Procurement related questions, contact US_Procurement-Policy@pwc.com; for Supplier Risk Management specific questions, contact US_Supplier-Risk-Management-Office@pwc.com. record.pwc_title: Drafting your next engagement letter just got easier. Get to know our newest tool: Create
record.pwc_body: Drafting your next engagement letter just got easier. Get to know our Drafting your next engagement letter just got easier. Get to know our newest tool: Create One Firm Risk Organization July 30, 2018 Create, our engagement letter creation system, is now available for all lines of service. Create makes drafting engagement letters, statements of work and other deliverables simpler, using a questionnaire structure to pull in the right firm-approved language. Built on the Exari platform, the system is easy to use and eliminates the need to edit our previous Word-based templates. We piloted Create across the firm and the feedback has been resoundingly positive. Along with DocuSign ,the electronic signature platform that also launches firmwide today, the shift underscores our firmwide strategy to simplify our internal process as well as become digital in all that we do as we improve the experience for our clients in these key contracting interactions. Create can help you by: Saving time and cost in preparing and reviewing documents -- giving you time back in your day Enhancing accuracy and quality -- helping you produce the right document in the right format at the start of the process Lowering risk by reducing the potential for manual errors Simplifying reviews by tracking and displaying any manual changes made to the template language When and how can I start using Create? Create is now available for all US lines of service. The tool will be available for Mexico engagement letters, statements of work and some deliverables later this fiscal year. Our Create site has all the materials you’ll need to get started, including FAQs, demo videos and quick reference guides for Assurance and Advisory users. Tax users will continue to access “Create for Tax” through Engagement Center, or from the OFRO Tax (formerly Tax Q&RM) Engagement Letters microsite. How does Create work? Our Create team combed through all the language in existing Word templates, including underlying footnotes, to build a contracting platform that’s easier to use and maintain. All of those pesky footnotes that required reading and editing have been transformed into questions in the system that you answer with the click of a button. No more wording changes, wrestling with footnotes, or changing fonts and colors. To put that effort in perspective: For Assurance alone, the Create team reviewed each of the 60+ Assurance templates available in US Template Manager -- more than 5,000 paragraphs of text. We standardized the language Create will use to build your draft to fewer than 400 paragraphs. All data entered in Create can also be data-mined by the new One Firm Risk Organization (OFRO), ASM&T and OGC for better risk management decisions, and all letters are stored centrally for easy access. Create for Tax currently integrates with DMS when used with Engagement Center. Executed tax letters from clients are automatically filed to DMS as they are returned. Integration with Aura is also planned to allow Assurance to upload completed letters to the EGAs seamlessly. Additional capabilities include: Document access is automatically set using the underlying engagement acceptance forms contained in the A&C system. Partners and Managers on the EAFs are granted rights to their own client content. For Assurance engagements, access is also guided by Aura rights. Additional drafters can be added manually, giving you the flexibility to add team members directly to a document, without impacting A&C or Aura. For staff who transition to other engagements, real-time adjustments will carry through to the system, automatically adjusting their access. Create will store seven years of content in the system, in accordance with our data retention policy. What’s next for Create? The team is already at work to bring other streamlined documentation onto Create for late 2018, including opinions, memos, SEC services documents, comfort letters and more. Create is also built for integration with other new technologies the firm is rolling out to simplify the client acceptance and engagement startup processes. Coming later this summer, the new Rapid Engage tool will help you get from opportunity identification to WBS code release faster. And Create will be integrated with DocuSign, our new electronic document signing system in late 2018. Have feedback or ideas for enhancing Create? Provide them here for consideration. Top News

record.pwc_title: Our purpose in action: Those 'important problems' are everywhere, and so are the digital solutions
record.pwc_body: Our purpose in action: Those 'important problems' are everywhere, and Our purpose in action: Those 'important problems' are everywhere, and so are the digital solutions Responsible Business Leadership April 16, 2018 Just a few months into her time at PwC as a campus hire, Lauren Bauer knew her team was facing a problem: how to best make use of vast amounts of publicly available data from the Department of Labor. Lauren, a Global Human Resource Solutions Tax associate, didn’t let being new to the firm (or the working world) stop her from taking digital fitness into her own hands. She taught herself Alteryx and developed a solution that’s now saving hundreds of hours of work and opening up the door to new client opportunities. Here’s more from Lauren: PwC Inside: Tell us a bit about the challenge your team was facing. Lauren Bauer: We knew there had to be a way to easily compare the publicly available data on benefits and pension plans that all companies file with the Department of Labor through a Form 5500. The information was out there, but no one had organized it or figured out an automated way to analyze it that would offer insights to current and potential clients. How did you approach it and what results have you seen? We had an idea that there might be a way to use technology to streamline the process, and I was excited to explore it more. With guidance from our resident Alteryx “ninja” Ming Fang, I worked in my spare time to build my knowledge of Alteryx and Tableau, and designed a tool that would allow us to compare companies’ data. My team, and my manager in particular, trusted me to teach them the new technology as we went along -- even as they were reviewing my work. They trusted me to guide them, even though I was the most junior person on the team. Now, work that would have taken hundreds of hours can now be done in a few minutes, allowing our team to focus on the analysis. We’re starting to identify companies that would benefit from working with us, and, as a result, already have two wins under our belt. What inspires you to make an impact on your team and PwC more broadly? Being new to the firm, I was excited to bring something to the table for my team. I love learning new things and exploring new tools -- before this project, I didn’t know what a Form 5500 was! I take pride in solving problems. Internally, this meant figuring out how we can create and use better tools and then externally, for our clients, how we can use public data to solve a problem. I feel that, in general, the firm can learn a lot by looking to new people who don’t know how things were done before. These are the people who have a fresh perspective on how to approach challenges, leading to new ways of doing things that are more efficient for everyone. To learn more about Lauren’s winning Alteryx / Tableau solution and how you could apply it to your engagement, contact Lauren, Kristin Harel or Michael Cardillo. In support of Your Tomorrow, the Tax practice is accelerating the journey to digitize work, enabling staff at all levels to focus on developing critical digital, tax technical and consultative skills and spend more high-value time with clients. Lauren’s successful use of technology to dramatically streamline work for her engagement embodies the purpose of this strategy, known as Digitizing Tax: Project 5 Million. To support the strategy, Tax has created an interactive community that houses our colleagues’ data workflows, visualizations and BOTS in a single, easily accessible location. The community will facilitate seamless collaboration among users. Stay tuned for more information in the coming weeks about this community -- and in the meantime, get a head start by taking the on-demand self-service analytics trainings, available here on Digital Hub. Our purpose as a firm is to build trust in society and solve important problems. Those problems can be large or small -- sometimes all it takes is a fresh pair of eyes and a different approach to find the one that you’ll solve. No matter what our role, we all have opportunities to go above and beyond to deliver our work and find meaning in what we do every day. How does our purpose resonate with you? Share your stories with us! To learn more about purpose at PwC, visit our Purpose Spark page. Lauren with her team Top (L-R): Dov Fiskus, Mike Cardillo, Gio Zammiello, Kristin Harel; Bottom (L-R): Lauren Bauer, Mike Boro Top News

record.pwc_title: Tax Accounting Service engagements for non-audit clients – approval requirements
record.pwc_description: These engagements must be approved by a TAS Market Leader or a GHRS Accounting Services Leader; see a new requirement for restricted status in DMS.
record.pwc_body: Tax Accounting Service engagements for non-audit clients – approval re Tax Accounting Service engagements for non-audit clients – approval requirements One Firm Risk Organization Nov. 9, 2018 Tax accounting service (“TAS”) engagements present unique and potentially significant risk to the firm, primarily as a result of the engagement’s relationship to our client’s financial statements. Such engagements include the following: Tax provision preparation or review Accounting for uncertain tax positions Tax accounting performance improvement GHRS Pension/OPEB valuation, stock-based compensation accounting or deferred tax related services (ASC 712, 715, 718 and/or 740). Because of the risk profile of such engagements, tax engagement teams should be aware of the risk management protocols to help teams mitigate the risks on these engagements. One such protocol requires that all tax accounting service engagements for non-audit clients be approved by a TAS Market Leader or a GHRS Accounting Services Leader. In addition, tax accounting service engagements that have been designated as high risk require OFRO Tax approval and the approval and active involvement of a Concurring Partner (“CP”) with tax accounting experience. Effective 11/7/2018, all non-restricted (C2) Tax provision review/preparation engagements are required to be restricted in DMS (see the Policy: Confidentiality and DMS access). All approvals should be obtained during the engagement acceptance process and prior to the execution of the engagement contract and the commencement of work. Engagement teams should select the characteristics that apply to the engagement when completing the A&C engagement acceptance assessment to ensure the appropriate approvals are obtained during the Engagement Acceptance process. When providing tax accounting services for non-audit clients, the engagement set-up sequence is important… Check restriction in Salesforce (or Central Entity Service (“CES”)) to determine if client is a non-audit client If a non-audit client, initiate the engagement acceptance assessment in A&C Obtain TAS/GHRS leader approval and, if applicable, OFRO Tax and CP approvals Execute engagement contract Begin work For additional information regarding tax accounting services for non-audit clients, see the Providing Tax Accounting Services to C2 Clients policy. Please note that a different approval process applies to engagements subject to the policy set forth in section 12370 of the PwC Audit Guide for Accounting Advisory Services to Non-Audit Clients. Contact any member of the OFRO Tax team with questions. Top News

record.pwc_title: How we’re celebrating our LGBT+ community
record.pwc_description: June is Pride month, and we’re bringing our values to life by unveiling new LGBT+ global branding and hosting our first-ever global summit for our PwC community.
record.pwc_body: How we’re celebrating our LGBT+ community How we’re celebrating our LGBT+ community Office of Diversity June 3, 2019 June is Pride month, when we “shine” a light on our LGBT+ community and recognize the impact the group has had on history locally, nationally and internationally. At PwC, we are using this time to celebrate the contributions of our LGBT+ community, reinforce our commitment to our LGBT+ colleagues and create a sense of belonging for all. We are starting the month with the introduction of a new global brand for our LGBT+ efforts — Shine. Shine represents our commitment to spotlighting and supporting our LGBT+ colleagues and the issues facing their community, while also uniting our LGBT+ community around the globe with one name. “Taking inspiration from the bright shining colors in a rainbow, an iconic LGBT+ symbol, this new name signifies how our people shine a light on the important issues that impact the LGBT+ community — and how they bring their authentic selves to work every day. By working to build trust in society, making our workplace and culture stronger, and creating brighter opportunities, PwC’s LGBT+ community helps each and every one of PwC’s people truly shine,” said Jeff Bharkhda, US Shine partner champion. We’ll mark Pride month in a number of ways, including supporting a team of 100 riders and roadies from around the globe in the AIDS Lifecycle ride from San Francisco to Los Angeles. The PwC team has raised more than $1 million to support AIDS research, making us the top corporate team fundraiser for three years in a row. At the end of the month, more than 160 delegates of Shine from across the globe will gather in New York City for our first-ever Global LGBT+ Summit. During the program, delegates will discuss issues affecting the firm and the LGBT+ community at large, hear from internal and external speakers who will share their experiences and insights, and discuss best practices that can be applied in their day-to-day interactions. Want to make your own impact? Get involved and learn more: - Gain a better understanding of gender inclusivity, use of pronouns and how to be more cognizant that not everyone uses traditional pronouns. - Learn more about our Gender Inclusivity and Transition Guidelines that outline PwC's approach to supporting transgender professionals. - Learn more about the Shine Network and how you can get involved. - See how we’ve demonstrated our commitment to the LGBT+ community over the past 15 years. Contact: angela.j.williams@pwc.com Top News

record.pwc_body: iMentor is looking for PwC volunteers! iMentor is looking for PwC volunteers! 300 Madison Office July 17, 2019 iMentor is looking for PwC volunteers to work with high school students one-on-one to leverage their own personal, educational and professional experiences to help students succeed. iMentor matches students in NYC high schools with committed college-educated mentors, equipped to guide that young person on their journey to college graduation. Through this program, you simply send a weekly email and meet once a month to empower a student to graduate high school and pursue their college aspirations. The hours you contribute to this organization count toward PwC’s Access Your Potential commitment. For more information, please attend one of our information sessions this summer: July iMentor Information Session Date: Wednesday, July 24, 2019 Time: 12:30pm to 1:30pm Location: 300 Madison – 22302 Lincoln Center Sign up to attend the July iMentor information session August iMentor Information Session Date: Wednesday, August 21, 2019 Time: 12:30pm to 1:30pm Location: 300 Madison – 22302 Lincoln Center Sign up to attend the August iMentor information session What is the program time commitment? The iMentor model provides flexibility to enable their mentors to volunteer even with a busy work schedule. Getting involved with iMentor is a great way to do something outside of client service that is truly impactful. 1.) Weekly email communication (3 times a month) - iMentor will provide a weekly writing prompt / topic for each Mentor and student to exchange to promote targeted, in-depth discussions addressing college readiness and success. 2.) Monthly in person meetings (once a month) - Mentors and students get together for in-person meetings, lasting two hours. The events and locations for these in-person meetings are all arranged by iMentor. All that is required of you as a Mentor is to attend. Questions about iMentor or looking to volunteer? The PwC champions for the iMentor program are Tamir, Zinger, Conor Queenan and Sean Hill. If you are interested in volunteering or learning more about iMentor please reach out to Tamir, Conor or Sean. Contact: conor.e.queenan@pwc.com Top News

record.pwc_title: Check off this list before you check out
record.pwc_body: Check off this list before you check out Check off this list before you check out PwC Technology June 28, 2018 Here’s a handy checklist to help you make a smooth exit for the firmwide shutdown. We hope you’ll take full advantage of this opportunity to disconnect from your work technology. IT Customer Support is still here to help if you need it. While local IT Customer Support is closed, you can use our other support options or visit PwC’s new service hub. It's an easy way to search for answers to your question, place orders, make support requests, resolve issues and find support options for IT, human capital, finance and other internal support services. Submit your time and expenses by June 29 to avoid delinquency notices, errors or expense/AmEx issues. Submit any lingering invoices to avoid delays in payment. Add this calendar reminder to double-check you’ve cleared your AmEx buffer and submitted all expenses in the legacy Mobile Expense system before we switch to the new expense system on July 17. Set your out-of-office notification. (Tip: Download the updated Out of Office app from PwC’s App Store … setting up your out-of-office alerts has never been so easy!) Enable call forwarding if you expect to receive critical calls. Traveling abroad? Your phone already has international roaming -- please use it responsibly. Don’t forget your passwords. But if you do, you can easily reset them. Replicate Aura data to avoid data loss or replication issues. Power down your PC. Not only is it time to check out, but when you turn it on, the proper updates will automatically install -- and you can hit the ground running when you come back to work. Clear your workspace. Put away files, and secure or take your laptop home. Top News

record.pwc_title: HQ FAQs
record.pwc_description: Get started with HQ! Learn more about this exciting platform with a list of frequently asked questions.
record.pwc_body: HQ FAQs General Information What is HQ? HQ is the Firm's new intranet platform, replacing myKcurve, PwC's legacy intranet of more than 10 years. This new site, powered by Adobe Experience Manager, further drives our Your Tomorrow strategy by serving as a modern, personalized portal that's your front door to firmwide and LoS news, tools and resources. PwC HQ is designed to give you easier access to the information you need to work, day in and day out. The user-friendly interface thoughtfully streamlines navigation and content so that you have on-demand access to the top apps and sites that you use on a daily basis. Fun fact: the name HQ (an abbreviation for headquarters) was chosen by our partners and staff back in January when we launched a survey to choose the name for our new intranet. Over 6,400 of you voted on the first piece of bringing this new site to life! For more information, refer to the About HQ page. What are some of the key features of HQ? The first release of HQ is called an “MVP - Minimum Viable Product” launch, which means that this is just the beginning and HQ will continue to be enhanced in the coming months. The following features are currently included: New look and feel, mobile-friendly user experience Streamlined navigation (fewer navigation items, more intuitive ways to get to underlying content, customizable Quick Links) Personalization (content across the site is targeted according to your personal attributes e.g. LoS, Sector, location) Key Dates (see upcoming firmwide events and add them to your Google calendar with one click) Stay tuned for more information on future enhancements. What will be included in future releases? Our HQ roadmap will continue to be refined and grow in the coming months. Right now, key items for our product roadmap include: Integrate predictive data and insights from the new myMetrics; Astro alignment Integrate key sites and systems into HQ search (align with enterprise search/Fathom on the front end) Expand personalization/preferences and analytics Mexico portal migration (via Spark) Partner Portal evaluation and approach Email/newsletter solution alignment and integration Collaboration platform alignment Is myKcurve going away? The front-end staff experience of myKcurve will no longer be available. However, the partner portal, also on Kcurve, will not be turned off in June and will be available to partners through personalized navigation. Is HQ available on mobile? The first release is "mobile-responsive." Post MVP, we will move towards "mobile-native," or an experience that can be fully realized in app format (with app notifications). Will HQ have social and/or collaboration functionality? You will have the ability to share content from HQ with other partners and staff. More community functionality (commenting and liking, for example) will be introduced in future releases of HQ. The US firm is currently exploring options for firmwide collaboration tools. Once that decision has been made, the approved solution for collaboration may be integrated into the HQ experience. Is HQ replacing Spark? No, HQ is not replacing Spark. The firm is in the process of reviewing collaboration and self-service web creation tools that will support the future demands of our Your Tomorrow agenda, but for now, we will still use Spark. With that said, there is content on Spark that is integral to our new digital workplace experience -- content that represents our firm strategy, structure and values -- that we will evaluate and update for potential migration onto HQ. Is HQ available in Mexico? The Mexico portal experience will remain on Spark in the near-term but we are looking to migrate it to HQ in FY20. Is HQ available to contractors or employees outside the US? Our contractor and PwC global employees will not have the personalization features in HQ that are available to our US employees (as these are pulled from Workday), but they will be able to view the content. How can I personalize my HQ experience? On Day 1, you can enhance your HQ experience by populating your Quick Links and ensuring that your personalization settings are properly set. The personal attributes (according to Workday) that will inform the content that you see in your homepage news feed and suggested Quick Links are: line of service, sector/subsector and location. You can see the attributes from your Workday profile by clicking the person link in the top right corner of your HQ screen. How can I find information outside of my personalized areas? If you are looking for content that isn’t personalized to you (e.g., you’re in Advisory and looking for information or news from Assurance), use Search and then filter by any LoS. In the future, we will be adding additional personalization features and you will also have the ability to subscribe to news from other lines of service, sectors and locations. How can I customize my Quick Links? Quick Links are designed to give you one-click access to the sites and systems you frequent most (see visual here). You have ten Quick Links available in your left hand navigation. Four of those ten Quick Links have been pre-populated based on your role at the firm, e.g., Tax Source for a Tax employee, or Consulting Source for an Advisory employee. All Quick Links can be edited, including the ones that are pre-populated. Staff can choose Quick Links by selecting the HQ Link Index, which will open an index of ~400 sites and systems that staff frequent most. You can add or remove a Quick Link by selecting the + or - button to the right of the link in the Link Index. How can I find my LoS/function information? You will see personalized news appear on the HQ homepage, specific to your LoS, sector and location. LoS communications and change teams will continue to create and publish content. In addition, you can find the LOS homepages in the “Our Clients and Business” navigation menu and these pages will link out to other areas. How can I provide feedback on HQ? Visit the HQ feedback community to share your ideas for product enhancements, see what others have suggested and vote on the ideas you’d like to see come to life. Your participation in this feedback tool will help the HQ team identify and prioritize enhancements to the site’s user experience, influencing the site’s user experience and product roadmap. How can I search on HQ? HQ makes it easier to access the information you need to deliver for our clients and our firm, and do so more efficiently. The HQ search functionality is a simplified experience that provides a single search bar, instead of the toggle search functionality available previously on myKcurve. Therefore, HQ search results will only display content (i.e., pages, microsites) and news (firmwide and LoS) that are native to HQ and will not surface all results from the sources that could be found on the myKcurve search bar (e.g., Fathom, A&A, Tax Source). Over time, HQ search will become more robust as we integrate with other platforms. Please stay tuned for updates on the timing of these, and other, HQ enhancements. In the meantime, access to individual search repositories, including Fathom, A&A and Tax Source, can be added as Quick Links or found in the Link Index. Will I be able to set reminders of my own on HQ? Yes, you can add certain firmwide key dates to your calendar. Navigate to the “Key Dates” section of HQ and click the “add to calendar” icon for available events. Once Astro, PwC’s cognitive agent, is launched firmwide, we will add the ability for you to see a more personalized list of “To Dos,” including a view of any tasks that you’ve set in Google Tasks and those added via Astro. How can I request new pages to be added to HQ? If you’d like to develop a new HQ page or migrate a site from another platform into HQ, please contact the HQ Team. Where do I go if I experience issues with HQ? If you have general questions/ comments about your HQ experience or need feedback community support, contact the HQ Team. For technical assistance with HQ (e.g., report bugs, personalization settings not working), please submit a request through Service Hub. Need additional help? Tech support HQ bugs and requests for technology support should be directed to Service Hub. Requests for content To request new HQ content/pages or changes to existing content/pages, please contact the HQ Team. Feedback Visit the HQ feedback community to share your ideas for product enhancements, see what others have suggested and vote on the ideas you’d like to see come to life.

record.pwc_title: About HQ
record.pwc_description: This page includes additional information for getting started with our new intranet platform, HQ -- including HQ Pages, News, Search, Links, and Personalization. This page will be kept up to date with stories and updates related to new platform enhancements and integrations.
record.pwc_body: About HQ Get started with HQ! Click below to learn more about this exciting platform. About HQ HQ is our new intranet platform, replacing myKCurve. This modern digital workplace will serve as your front door to firmwide and LoS news, tools and resources. Together with myMetrics 2.0 and Astro, HQ is part of our journey toward an integrated digital experience across the firm. HQ Pages Each page within HQ is managed by a specific PwC team or function. If you have questions about content other than the HQ home page, please submit them through the “Questions for the Team” link on the page you are viewing. To request new HQ content/pages or changes to existing content/pages, please contact the HQ team. Need more help finding the content you need? Check out our Quick Reference Card. News News is personalized on the HQ home page, from top to bottom of the page by LoS, Sector, Sub-sector and Location. In addition, you'll see key firmwide news at the top of your page and in your news feed. The PwC Inside email will continue to be sent on Tuesdays and Fridays. New content will also be posted on the HQ home page regularly throughout the week. If you have a piece of news you’d like to submit, please email our editorial team. Search Search results display content (pages, microsites) and news (firmwide and LoS) native to HQ and do not include links from the Link Index (the Link Index can be filtered from within the Link Index page) Initially, searches won’t surface all of the results from Fathom, Accounting & Auditing (A&A), Tax Source, etc. that could be found from the search bar on myKcurve. But in subsequent releases, HQ search will integrate with these other platforms and display those results in addition to content and news native to HQ. In the meantime, the individual repositories for search - like Fathom, Accounting & Auditing (A&A) and Tax Source - can be added as Quick Links, or they can also be found in the Link Index. Quick Links Quick Links provide you easy access to your favorite applications and resources. By default, you are provided with a set of priority Quick Links, chosen by your LoS. You can change these or add more for a total of ten custom Quick Links. To add more, click “Add to quick links” (or “Edit quick links” if you have ten already set), search or browse for your favorite app, then select “+” to add it to your Quick Links. To remove one, click “-”. Personalization Your HQ experience is personalized, based on the data assigned to you in Workday. Currently, personalization is driven by your LoS, Sector, Sub-sector and Location (Market or Office). Future releases will expand personalization, as will HQ’s artificial intelligence that learns your search preferences the more you use it. HQ News and Quick Links are personalized to you. If you are looking for content that isn’t personalized to you (e.g., you’re in Advisory and looking for information or news from Assurance), use Search and then filter by any LoS. Need additional help? Tech support HQ bugs and requests for technology support should be directed to Service Hub. Requests for content To request new HQ content/pages or changes to existing content/pages, please contact the HQ team. FAQs Please see the attached list of Frequently Asked Questions about HQ. Feedback Visit the HQ feedback community to share your ideas for product enhancements, see what others have suggested and vote on the ideas you’d like to see come to life. News If you have a piece of news you’d like to submit, please email our editorial team.

record.pwc_title: Data Use Policies
record.pwc_body: Data Use Policies Marketing & Sales Campaign Data Use Policy Internal and external campaigning Sales Event Data Use Policy Any event leading to pipeline generation revenue Opportunity Data Use Policy Data when attracting and developing new business Human Capital Person Skillset Data Use Policy PwC Employee skills for the purpose of placing the right people on the right teams Compensation / Benefits Data Use Policy Compensation and Benefits data includes salary, and benefits Internal Person / Employee Data Use Policy Anyone working on behalf of PwC i.e. PII , Job Role, Manager, Hire & Termination date Recruitment Data Use Policy Any data acquired during a recruitment event or of candidates we are recruiting Partner Affairs Data Use Policy All data pertaining to partners, which is housed across multiple systems/platforms (core HRIS Data, performance documents, succession planning, payroll data, wealth creation, benefits, retirement calculations, etc) Incident Management Incident Management Data Use Policy ServiceNow / APM Vendor Relationship Vendor Relationship Data Use Policy Master Data about our Vendors (to include relationship and product/service offerings, independence) Learning & Development L&D Course Catalogue Data Use Policy L&D data on the course itself i.e. instructor, duration, course number L&D Training Transcript Data Use Policy Transactional data on who and what L&D training occurred CPE Credits & Compliance Data Use Policy Employee ID, CPA licence #, licence expiration date, state etc Client Data Client Data Use Policy - Primary and Secondary Use A “Primary Use” of Client Data is (1) any task that is performed in the course of delivering services (2) any task performed in support of service delivery, including client pursuit, engagement start-up, client billing, required compliance activities, entity management, client relationship management, and development, testing, or maintenance of systems and tools used to deliver services; or (3) development of machine learning algorithms or tools which are further used or distributed without the underlying Client Data. A “Secondary Use” of Client Data is any other use of Client Data, including (1) use in development, testing, or maintenance of systems, tools, or methodologies not in conjunction with service delivery; or (2) (must be de-identified) inclusion in data sets used for data analysis or insight generation not performed for that same client. Clients' Tax Forms Data Use Policy The Tax form records PwC receives from our Clients about their business. Corporate Clients' Financial Data Use Policy The financial records PwC receives from our Clients about their business. Risk Management Pricing Finance Markets & Sectors OGC Knowledge Public Third Party Have an update? Please submit any requests to add or update policies listed on this page through Service Hub. Questions? US_Chief-Data-Office-Consultations@pwc.com
